content.webTitle: Horace and Pete: Louis CK’s surprise new web series is dark and difficult

fields.headline: Horace and Pete: Louis CK’s surprise new web series is dark and difficult
fields.bodyText: It’s easy to say that Louis CK “pulled a Beyoncé” when he posted the first episode of his new series Horace and Pete for download on his website Saturday. That’s not really true. When Beyoncé posted an album online unexpectedly, we all knew what it was. It was a complete set of songs (along with videos). It was an already established format on iTunes, which was, by then, an established platform. This thing that Louis CK has presented to the public is, well, I don’t even know what. The 70-minute first episode certainly is not a comedy. While there are a few humorous asides in the bar room chatter, the story won’t make you bust a gut – unless it’s a ritual disembowelment so that you can escape the pervasive misery of the series. Even if you take it as a drama, it looks more like theatre, filmed somewhat statically on two sets. But it’s not a play: it’s recorded and you’re watching it on your computer screen even though it feels like you’re in the middle of a five-hour production of The Iceman Cometh at BAM. Just what the hell is CK trying to pull off here? Horace and Pete refers to the bar that is the setting of the action as well as the two guys who own it, Horace (CK) and his brother Pete (Steve Buscemi). They’re the eighth Horace and Pete to run the establishment, which has been around for 100 years. Their Uncle Pete (Alan Alda) is the crotchety old bartender who uses the N-word repeatedly while trying to explain how he’s not racist. Horace is doing a terrible job running the bar and is being sued for control of it by his sister Sylvia (Edie Falco). He’s also on the outs with his two children. His daughter Alice (SNL’s Aidy Bryant) tells him he “knows what he did”, but we’re not privy to the details. It seems to have something to do with Horace’s live-in girlfriend Rachel (Rebecca Hall). The mood is decidedly dour, and the crux is Sylvia’s lawsuit against her brothers to try to dissolve the business. It seems as though CK is trying to explore issues around the difference between what is right and what is legal, what sort of legacy we have been left by our forefathers, and what a family looks like in the modern age. It’s funny that these questions are about how we live right now when the bar, with its aged furniture and tacky decor, could have come from any time over the past 50 years. But then Horace pulls out his iPhone to make a call and you’re snapped right back to the present. Not even the present: the show is set the day after it was released, which is literally yesterday. A newscaster talks about Trump stepping out of the Republican debate and the looming primary in Iowa. Bar patrons (including greats like Jessica Lange, Steven Wright and Nick DiPaolo) chatter about the upcoming Super Bowl, making specific references to the teams that will be in it, decided only a week ago. Most of the script could have been written any time, but that makes it clear those passages are fresh and it was filmed very recently. That is a refreshing urgency that we never get from television. That begs the question, yet again: what is CK up to? We know very little about this series, including how many episodes there will be, when the next one will be released – or really anything at all. The meager description offered on the site is as follows: “Hi there. Horace and Pete episode one is available for download. $5.” CK has had great success selling his wares directly to fans on his website, and his experiment with platform as well as format is part of what makes this project so audacious. But all of that experimentation makes Horace and Pete a little hard to watch. Viewers will spend as much time figuring out just what this thing is as they will what is going on and what it all means. That is not inherently bad – in fact it’s a good exercise in critical analysis – but difficult viewing turns off plenty of people. It’s so much easier to plunk down $5 when you know what you’re getting, like a standup comedy special, say, or a secret Beyoncé album. Even harder to swallow will be the difficulty of the material itself. It is dark. A million miles deep in a coal mine at midnight with no moon and wearing a blindfold dark. It’s sad and depressing and not very easily untangled, like the best American plays. You know the ones – those that you’re forced to read in school because no one would willingly pick them up because there isn’t enough Lexapro at your local CVS. That doesn’t make Horace and Pete bad, it just makes it hard and Louis CK is always at his best when he’s challenging expectations. This series isn’t going to be for everyone, but all of the disorientation and ingenuity certainly make it one of the most thrilling things to come along in some time.
